This comment needs waaay more context. It took me ages to understand what you were getting at. I _think_ what you're saying is that 'FlavorImageConflict' derives from 'NovaException', and the 'code' attribute of this exception is set to 500, meaning we'll get a HTTP 5xx if this is raised in e.g. the API.

Assuming I've grokked this correctly then this is a fair point that does need to be addressed. However, simply changing this won't fix everything since I didn't introduce that exception with this change. We have existing users and currently raise it from places likes 'get_mem_encryption_constraint' which is called by the same '_validate_flavor_image_numa_pci' helper in 'nova.compute.api.API' (via '_validate_flavor_image_mem_encryption') that you're worried about here. As such, fixing this in a piecemeal fashion like this isn't good enough. We need to change the base class of the 'FlavorImageConflict' exception first.

Okay, this isn't an issue because we're explicitly handling 'FlavorImageConflict'. The exception you're worrying about can be raised via the following call stack:

  nova.api.openstack.compute.servers.ServersController.create
   nova.compute.api.API.create
    nova.compute.api.API._create_instance
     nova.compute.api.API._checks_for_create_and_rebuild
      nova.compute.api.API._validate_flavor_image
       nova.compute.api.API._validate_flavor_image_nostatus
        nova.compute.api.API._validate_flavor_image_numa_pci
         nova.virt.hardware.get_vif_multiqueue_constraint

However the call to 'nova.compute.api.API.create' in 'nova.api.openstack.compute.servers.ServersController.create' has an explicit exception handler for 'FlavorImageConflict' via the INVALID_FLAVOR_IMAGE_EXCEPTIONS attribute [1][2]. We also have similar exception handlers for resize and rebuild. So, ultimately, we don't need this.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/75f719e0/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L854-L855
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/75f719e0/nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py#L55-L58

i dont agree with this by the way

if we want to have only 2 classes of storage we should refer to them as volume backed and non volume backed.

using cinder volume does not give you better volume persitince or resilance then non vovlume strage take the lvm cinder backend as an exmaple or many san based soltion without internal ha.

using nvme over frabic often has no ha so if that disk dies your data is gon just as if the disk on the local storage died.

when you use the rbd imageage backeend it has the same persitnace guarentees as a ceph cinder volume.

epmeral and persitence have other implications and use ephemral to refer to root and not root disk is confusing more on that below.

no we really should not refer to the root disk as part of epmeral storage

its not its tied to the lifetime of the instace yest but tha tis not what makes epmeral storage epmeral.

we should only use ephemeral to refer to the extra disk provded by flavor.epmermeral.

the root disk is its own thing. we have 3 types of storage and we should not try and group the root disk with addtioanl epmeral storage as we have very differnt guarnetees for them with regards to snapshots, evaculattion, rebuild and resize.

kubernetes/cni/bond-cni/centos/bond-cni..message: If you wrote this file from scratch you may want to slap a copyright header onto it.

I guess nobody ever bumped the version numbers, hence why the sha is required on the tarball names?  If that's the case I'd recommend that the short version of the commit sha %{shortcommit} be appended to the Version number.  The resulting .rpm of the build should look something like bond-cni-1.0-bff6422d.tis.1.rpm

With this latest patchset, the rpm looks like:

bond-cni-1.0-bff6422.tis.1.x86_64.rpm

I've had to embed the shortcommit in the 'Release' tag.  Adding it to the 'Version' directly causes an rpm build error complaining about too many '-' characters in the Version.

Looking at the few other places we do something similar, it looks like the same tagging is done via the 'Release':

puppet-staging-1.0.4-1.b466d93git.el7.tis.3.src.rpm
https://opendev.org/starlingx/integ/src/branch/master/config/puppet-modules/puppet-staging/centos/meta_patches/0001-Update-package-versioning-for-TIS-format.patch#L19

puppet-rabbitmq-5.6.0-4.5ac45degit.el7.tis.2.src.rpm
https://opendev.org/starlingx/integ/src/branch/master/config/puppet-modules/puppet-rabbitmq-5.5.0/centos/meta_patches/0001-Update-package-versioning-for-TIS-format.patch#L19

Ok, this looks more like a datestamp, but the same idea:

net-tools-2.0-0.24.20131004git.el7.tis.6.x86_64.rpm
https://opendev.org/starlingx/integ/src/branch/master/networking/net-tools/centos/meta_patches/spec-to-include-TiS-patches.patch#L20

You still need the version in the rpm filename to represent an *exact* version as I recommend by using the short commit id.  Otherwise from the name of the rpm file nobody really knows what exact upstream version it is as 1.0 is too vague.  Having to dig around in stx repos to determine an exact upstream version is a #fail.

Yeah, v1.0 was released years ago.  There has been a bit more activity recently, but for the most part the extra commits seems to be a few bug fixes and compatibility updates to work with new k8s/vendor packages.  As my testing showed, it seems to work flawlessly. The only thing I could really see in the future is support for more bonding options as per https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/networking/bonding.txt
There it is.  For some reason my eyeballs didn't notice this last time.  Sorry about that.

deployment/iscsid/iscsid-container-puppe.message:
The problem is that containers don't start immediately. We need some time to start them or a loop that checks that there are no containers that are about to start. Once all of them are started we can compare and stop containers that were not run before. 

TL;DR sleep 5 fixes the issue

If possible I would prefer if we implement a busy waiting instead of sleeping 5 seconds by default... if we leave it like this we will be adding 5 seconds for free to every node we run the hybrid state in, which translates in several seconds in big environments.
If we actively check if the service is running (or perform a ping to the service like done here: https://stackoverflow.com/a/69921248 ) and wait if it isn't will turn into most cases a 1 second wait (or directly continueing) and 5 seconds in the worst case.
I know this approach is more tedious, but it will save us upgrade time.

The behavior of the API won't have changed, but one of the clients will have chosen to enforce a sensible limit. Just an idea

I proposed such an alternative here [1]. Feel free to squash this in if you can get the neutron community to buy in (which I'm hoping you can - the "no force" behavior by default is a lot safer and it aligns behavior between the networking and compute services)

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-openstackclient/+/819627/1

Ufff, do no open the Pandora box again!

When I proposed this feature, I realize that Neutron API behaves different to Nova. Nova, by default, checks the quota limits. With --force, Nova will push any value.

In Neutron we have the opposite behaviour, the API accepts everything, regardless of the current resource usage. The output of the community was clear: the current behaviour must not change. This is why I proposed (and it was accepted) a new CLI knob: --check-limit

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
this is a soft -1 i don't  think there is any harm in makeing this configuratble however we will need a specless blueprint to track this change. you already have a release note that is good and have provided documentation that is part of the config option. you might want to consider extending the install guide or other admin docs on cold migration to make note of this but i think what you have in the current versions is sufficent.

there is no upgrade impact since the defualt list is the same.
while it might produce asymetic behaivor if you dont set this the same on all host i dont think it
should break anything so i dont see any upgrade concerns form that aspect either so i dont belive this needs a spec.

Thanks Sean for the quick and comprehensive review.

Ideally, I think it makes sense for most environments to also change the default value (or disable compression completely?). Based on my tests, in networks 10G, compression is slowing things down. Do you think it would stall the process (or require additional specs) to do so?
I'd rather have that configurable without changing the default than to get the whole thing get stuck somewhere in the pipeline if it needs further debate.

how big where the root disk you were testing with and how compressible where they?
is there an infleciton point in your data eg. <20G no copresssion is better >500G compression wins?

there are two remote file system dirver by the way

the ssh driver just adds the -C option to enable stream compression at the ssh level when establishing the connection to the remote server.

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/50fdbc752a9ca9c31488140ef2997ed59d861a41/nova/virt/libvirt/volume/remotefs.py#L192-L193

for ssh it may in fact slow things down on a high speed link but the rsync driver may scale better so if we were to change the default the new default would have to work for both drivers.

i actully dont think it makes sense to disbale compression by default at least not on  <10G networks. 25G+ probably would be better off with compression disabled in some caes  but if you want to change the behavior to disbale compression by default then we need to discuss the upgrade impacts exctra which may require a spec.

we would certenly at least want to know how you tested, the type of data in the disk (empty, text, imcompresable video, db) and are there any hardware factors that might come into play.

a 10G network is a realtivily slow network link in most datacenters today, i would expect copying a 100G raw image with compression if its relitivly spares/empty to be faster with compression then without but perhaps not.

for openstack deployment that still use 1G network (they do still exist) i woudl expect compression to help but if you can provide data for use to review we can certenly discuss a default change. i would suggest makeing an default change a follow up patch that we can review an accept/reject seperatly.

your current proposal make this configurable and you can tweak this in your deployment with your installer or manually so i think you already have a good compromise of being able to expand this for your usecaes without affecting existing usage.

i would keep this patch simple and potentially back portable and defer the rest to a second patch. not that i expect this to be backproted upstream nessisarly but without changing any beahivor by default that is at least an option.

Looks clear and simple. Please add a unit test to change. (similarly to the existing test nova.tests.unit.virt.libvirt.test_driver.LibvirtDriverTestCase.test_migrate_disk_and_power_off_swap) Once that test is done I will +2 this.

Please have a look at the previous change referred from the commit message.

At a high level, we had a security bug, we leaked traffic between ports plugged into the dead vlan. We had to install a flow (temporarily) for each of these ports to actually drop their traffic. But due to the the race condition described here (which we didn't realize was possible during the previous patch's review and testing until we hit some problems in the stable/victoria gate) the add-delete order may be wrong and then we leave the port dead.

Technically we add the dead vlan flow from dhcp/l3-agent, but we delete it from ovs-agent. So adding and deleting happens in two different processes. As soon as dhcp/l3-agents plug the port ovs-agent may start processing the same port. But dhcp/l3-agents also did not finish with the port when it was plugged, that's why the race is possible.

I also think this is far from optimal and it may cause some slowdown in ovs-agent's port processing. But the previous patch was created to fix a bug with possible security implications, so I believe fixing that is more important than some performance loss. Ideally we could fix the security bug without any performance loss. Please let me know if you see a way to do that.

Regarding the check you asked for: ovs_lib's replace_port() always puts the port into the dead vlan, so I think there's no need to further check it.

 Datapath actions: drop

But we have caveats:

1) If we implement the dead vlan this way, then all ports plugged into the dead vlan are able to communicate with each other on vlan 4095 (at least inside a compute host). vlan 4095 is a reserved vlan, so for example Linux does not allow a vlan subinterface with id 4095, but clearly if you can modify what's on the wire, you can use vlan 4095 as a valid vlan. ovs does not treat it in a special way. This already means that we must totally trust whatever is connected to a dead vlan port (all dhcp server and router implementations we allow). If they happen to have an independent vulnerability that may be combined with the fact, that they have a ready-made communication channel between each other crossing tenant separation.

2) Keep in mind that the normal action flow(s) are always the last flows in the flow table. Anything connected to dead vlan ports may try subverting all flows before the normal action flow. For example flows handling traffic towards physical bridges. This can happen even outside vlan 4095.

> > 2) Keep in mind that the normal action flow(s) are always the last flows in the flow table. Anything connected to dead vlan ports may try subverting all flows before the normal action flow. For example flows handling traffic towards physical bridges. This can happen even outside vlan 4095.

Those ports can send packets in any vlan. Those packets will be processed first in the openflow flow table, according to whatever we have there (for example vlan remapping flows for physical bridges). Only when the flow processing gets to the last flow (which has actions=NORMAL) will the normal switching pipeline actually drop those packets.

I will check all ideas we gathered here to see if we have a less problematic approach to solve the original bug.

Until then I just wanted to add some notes about how to reproduce the problems here (all in a single host devstack). Unfortunately all of these rely on adding sleep()s, that's why these changes don't have proper tests.

1) To reproduce the original security bug, before the previous change was merged:

Add sleep() to make the original bug practically deterministic:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/commit/da9fd503cef53ae3f9701d57bf1f1bb388129107/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py#L1232

Create a bunch of subnets with the same range, therefore neutron picks the same dhcp port addresses, for which ipv6 duplicate address detection catches when the dead vlan leaks:
 for i in {1..5}
 do
    ( openstack network create xnet$i ; openstack subnet create xsubnet$i-v6 --ip-version 6 --network xnet$i --subnet-range 2001:db8::/32 ) &
 done

When the bug is present, usually all but one dhcp port addresses go into the dadfailed state.
When the bug is fixed there's no dadfailed address.
 for net in $( openstack network list -f value -c Name -c ID | awk '/ xnet/ { print $1 }' ) ; do sudo ip netns exec qdhcp-$net ip a ; done | egrep 'inet6 2001:db8::'

2) To exercise the race condition addressed in this change:

Add sleep() to force the delete_flows, add_flow order:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/commit/7aae31c9f9ed938760ca0be3c461826b598c7004/neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py#L399

Add sleep() to force the add_flow, delete_flows order:
https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/commit/7aae31c9f9ed938760ca0be3c461826b598c7004/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py#L1239

With the wrong order we leave a port dead, which can be detected by many tests, for example this:
 tempest.scenario.test_network_basic_ops.TestNetworkBasicOps.test_router_rescheduling

And after each of these failures we leave behind one of these flows:
 sudo ovs-ofctl dump-flows br-int | egrep -c priority=65534
Please check my comments on PS2

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/.message: nitty nit: maybe for better readability You can add empty line before and after definition of that function?
maybe instead of this loop You can use "wait_until_true" helper function here?

The port deletion is executed first because "strict=True". Check "do_action_flows" method. The "strict" and "non-strict" flows can't be executed in the same bundle. "strict" flow commands (deletion), are executed first.

Check [1] commit message and bug. This is something similar.

In this case, same as in [1], I think you can avoid "strict" flag removing the "priority" field. "priority" cannot be executed without "strict". But in this case doesn't matter: "in_port=port.ofport" must be unique, that means this is enough to find the flow we need to remove.

If you have an environment ready to reproduce this issue, I would first remove "strict" and "priority" fields from this command.

[1]https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/819900

It's an interesting point to not filter for priority and then we don't need strict=True. However please keep in mind that add_flow and delete_flows are executed from different processes (at least as long as we don't change the previous patch's approach). I see how using strict may change the timing of flow operations inside a process. But I don't see how it would change the transaction ordering between two processes. Am I missing something here?
We discussed this in the neutron channel and agreed strict=False won't eliminate the race between the two agents.

This is great work.  Thank you.  The socket policy definitely gives more flexible for optimization that could lead to better performance on a single socket and dual socket config with that caveat that a VM could fit nicely into 1 NUMA node, i.e. hw_numa_nodes=1.  Where hw_numa_nodes > 1 and there is only 1 PCI device on a 2 socket system, the possibility of spreading VM assignment across two socket will result in higher latency.  It's just something that we have to keep in mind when validating for the most optimal HW and SW configs.

affinity

processors'

Not really true. Cluster-on-Die (CoD) has been around for a long time but the lower number of NUMA nodes (meaning more CPUs and memory per node) meant sticking with strict NUMA affinity was still a reasonable proposition. Also, I think (from talking to Sean) the penalties on disabling CoD on these platforms and making multiple NUMA nodes appear as one wasn't as severe as the penalty we get with AMD Zen 2.

actuly it was about 70-80% of the penaltiy as going across socket but when intel moved to the mesh archatechture instead of rings buses it was reduced significantly.

it is still a resonable performace hit for itenl cpus even with a mesh however.
what has really changed is its now more apprent that this will afect multiple vendors and possible multiple architure so this is a more generic problem where as before it was niche to jsut intel in one specific configurtin that was disbaled by default.

cluster on die or sub numa clustering as it becamse was really aimed at hpc workloads but its also relevent for telcos and with amd zen basced chip its more releveln for more workloads effectivly all numa workloads.
Done
I don't think this is quite the issue. It's more that older processors did *not* have more than one NUMA node on a single socket, meaning we could roughly equate a NUMA node to a socket.

if older you mean pre haswell 
which was released in 2013 and post nehlem which was released in 2008


pre nehelm the memocy contoler was on the mother board so all systems were UMA.
from nehlem on the memory contoler moved to the cpu.

intel added cluster on die in 2013 with haswell and they reduced the perfoamcne impact in skylake
https://www.anandtech.com/show/8423/intel-xeon-e5-version-3-up-to-18-haswell-ep-cores-/4

the haswell chip with more then 10 cores had 2 or even 3 different internal partion which were interconnected with at least 1 memory contoler per ring. with cluster on die off the chip was presented as a singel numa node but with cluster on die on the physical toplogy fo the cpus was exposed to the os with each memory contoler running independely as its own numa region.

in when skylake was intoduced in 2017 it intoduced the mesh architrue
and also change the cache heriacy.
https://en.wikichip.org/wiki/intel/microarchitectures/skylake_(server)#Memory_Hierarchy
cluster on die was rebarnded as sub numa clustering
https://en.wikichip.org/wiki/intel/microarchitectures/skylake_(server)#Sub-NUMA_Clustering
with some other enhancements.

with the mesh toplogy the latency between cores/memoyc contoler was significantly reduced which masked the impact of not having socket affinty for singel socket servers as you can enable multiple numa nodes in the 1 socket and use the perfer policy. however since we dont have socket affinity currently it means that on multi socket systems using prefer could result in a pci device form a different socket which will have a signicant penelty due to needing to cross the QPI/UPI bus.

so this has been a issue for 7+ year although some hardware optimisation have hiddine it recently on the intel side it does affect both amd and intel to different degrees depending on the generation.

this likely also holds true for non x86 achitrues too.
Yeah, not sure what I was thinking writing this. Changed.

Since the purpose of ``socket`` is to prevent crossing the socket barrier to access the PCI device, with hw_numa_nodes=2 and policy=socket, both guest NUMA nodes would have to be on the same host socket (so your second paragraph is correct).

In fact, the presence of a single PCI device with policy=socket effectively forces all your guest NUMA nodes to come from the same host socket, regardless of how many there are. If there's a second PCI device with a different policy, nothing changes in how it's treated, *once* all non-same-socket host NUMA nodes have been eliminated from the possibilities.

When does this happen?

It's a tricky scenario. When doing a cluster upgrade and if the image_id changed in the new cluster template, Heat will trigger Nova instance rebuild during the cluster upgrade. As a result, all those 3 software deployments(kube_cluster_deploy, master_config_deployment and upgrade_kubernetes_deployment) will be triggerred with an unexpected order. And that's why I'm using depends_on to make sure upgrade_kubernetes_deployment will be run after master_config_deployment. And use "name" to make sure kube_cluster_deploy run after master_config_deployment, see http://greenstack.die.upm.es/2015/05/05/heat-softwareconfig-resources-primeroverview/

I hope that makes more sense now.

Wouldn't it make sense to drain the node at this point, if we know for the fact that it's about to be rebuilt? If for whatever reason it's not a good place to do that, is there some better way of ensuring that the node is drained before we rebuild it?

Hi Krzysztof, thanks for your comments. Unfortunately, we cannot do that. Because when this piece of code being run, the node has already been rebuilt. So we cannot drain the node here 😞

I'm thinking to leverage the pre-create or pre-update hook of Heat to 'pause' the process, so that we can get a chance to drain the node, but that probably means we have to use something running inside the cluster to trigger the drain action and then signal Heat to continue. Please let me know if you have a better idea. Cheers.

Thanks, I kind of expected that to be the case based on my previous findings but hope dies last - perhaps you could make the wording more explicit? Something like "Node rebuilt as part of the cluster update"?

I have to say, trying to figure out what exactly can be done in Heat has been an exercise in frustration. There was a blueprint draft started here that talked about adding support for what we seemingly need: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/update-hooks but the comment only mentions another blueprint that's supposed to "cover 99% or more of [usecases]". The aforementioned blueprint is https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/action-aware-sw-config but it's not clear to me what is actually implemented and how it works - I have a feeling that it doesn't, as SoftwareDeployment "depends" on the Server so I assume it will only start updating after server is rebuilt. Also, I don't think it's safe to upgrade master nodes (and etcd cluster) without some sort of global/shared lock anyway so that may be dead end anyway.

Perhaps you are right, and pre-update hooks are what we really should be using - I've looked into them but came to the same conclusion that some extra component running in the cluster are needed. But perhaps that's the case and there is no reason to look for something else? If so, what would the upgrade process look like? Is there a way for magnum to push information about pending update to the cluster component, or would it have to query magnum periodically?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: What's the reasoning for it's own command rather than being able to reuse the existing network vip provision command?

Putting -W as we need one more change here after reviewing [1].
Instead of building a new, fresh playbook (and a separated Ceph command), let's extend the existing cli (overcloud ceph deploy), embedding the VIP(s) creation (when we need them) during the ceph_nfs deployment.
It results in a flow which is consistent with the existing user experience (let's create the metal, the network, the vips, deploy ceph) and it's easier to maintain.
My next PS is going to reflect this behavior.
Thank you Harald, Brendan and Alex for your input so far.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/825679

So, I'm not sure having a separate command makes sense either. But I'm not strongly against it. I think this non-cohesive user experience very difficult to avoid when ceph is no longer a THT service. But ... I agree we should try to minimize it.

For the Redis and OVNDBs VIPs they are created as part of the service configuration. Since this VIP need to known up-front, it wont be possible to put it in `OS::TripleO::Services::CephIngress`.

I'm putting two ideas below, that we can consider. Not sure any is much better than what you already have. 


Could this call to the tripleo_service_vip ansible module be a part of the `overcloud ceph deploy` command which deploys ceph. With a condition based on weather the ceph part that need the VIP is enabled? And which network and potential fixed_ip for this VIP would go in the config file with all the other ceph settings? Or an argument for ceph deploy command, like the '--mon-ip'?


If there is a strong preference to use the 'network vip provision' command, I had a look at the code and it would be possible to add something to it's schema to tell the module[1] creating the `deployed_vip.yaml` Heat environment file to not include these specific vips.

So if vip_data.yaml look like: (Not sure `net_vip` is a good name).

  - network: ctlplane
  - network: storage
    subnet: storage_subnet01
  - name: ceph_nfs_vip
    network: storage
    subnet: storage_subnet01
    net_vip: false

`net_vip` defaults to true, but when false at [1] add a condition to skip that VIP so we don't add it to the Heat env file. And in [2], make it _not_ set the 'tripleo_vip_net' tag, set some other tag instead and update the remove_obsolete_ports() method to also handle this other tag. With a special tag it would be easy to do a lookup in neutron to find the vip, i.e for tripleo_ansible_inventory or something.



[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_overcloud_network_vip_populate_environment.py#L181
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_overcloud_network_vip_provision.py#L159

Hey Harald,
thanks for your input.
Let's put this review on hold until I review this requirement w/ the Ceph squad.
Like Redis and OVN, having those VIPs included in the ceph deployment process could be a valid option.

Hey Alex, as described in [1] we'd like to rely on CephIngress service for any Ceph HA configuration (which is related to ceph_nfs for now, but can be easily applied to RGW and the dashboard in the near future).
Assuming we're able to run this daemon, which is made by haproxy+keepalived on Controller nodes, we need to make sure the VIPs used by Ceph are not owned by pacemaker (it would be problematic having both keepalived and pacemaker managing the same VIP).
Now, using/rely on the network vip provision command was the original idea ... but, as pointed out by Harald in the tripleo_ceph_ingress_spec [1], we're able to provision 1 vip per network atm, which means that we can break services (see [4]) that are still using that VIP provisioned on the storage network (or any other network depending on the tht override specified).
Other services, like Redis and ovn, instead, create their vips during the overcloud deploy (step0) [2] through module [3], which is the same approach of this patch.
We moved to a new Ceph command due to the fact we need to have everything in advance (because of deployed Ceph).


[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-specs/+/824146/comment/aaa46ec3_54318d75/
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/deployment/ovn/ovn-dbs-container-puppet.yaml#L241
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/modules/tripleo_service_vip.py
[4] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml

I think it would be ideal if we can facilitate this as part of the existing VIP provision process. And I understand the limitation of one VIP per network that currently exists as you mention in: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-specs/+/824146/comment/aaa46ec3_54318d75/


I think if we can manage to modify the existing vip provision process, it would create a more cohesive user experience during the deployment. Since we're already adding multiple new steps that are likely to cause confusion as it is. Facilitating the requirements you have for Ceph ingress within the existing framework would be ideal if possible. 

But if @hjensas thinks it's better to have a seperate step for this and this would be too difficult to manage in the existing process then I guess this should be fine.
Ok. That info would have been good in the commit. I'm still not certain we should have a separate command but I'll leave that up to others to decide.

The obvious question is why do we need to do this every time kubelet starts rather than just on node bootup?

The answer to this should probably be added to the git commit message so that it's available for future code maintainers.

This is bootrap issue. When kubelet fails to start due to invalid arguments, we cannot unlock the host, even though that the configuration file is regenerated after reboot during init sequence.

Ideally we would also fix robustness of kubernetes kubelet so that it doesn't die. This used to work previously even in the case of HT bios changes since the accounting was using number of absolute cores rather than specific cpuset.

kubernetes/kubernetes-1.18.1/centos/file.message: I think meaning of this script would be clearer as 'sanitize'.
if this file is going to be identical across k8s versions, would it make sense to put it in the unversioned kubernetes package?
suppress stderr to /dev/null for this and subsequent examples; it's OK you are catching the return code anyway

To make more obvious what the grep is matching and sed is doing, explain the format of the string.

"Get reserved-cpus comma-separated-values string from environment file and strip double quotes"


Example format:
KUBELET_EXTRA_ARGS=--cni-bin-dir=/usr/libexec/cni --node-ip=abcd:204::2 --volume-plugin-dir=/usr/libexec/kubernetes/kubelet-plugins/volume/exec/ --fea
ture-gates TopologyManager=true --cpu-manager-policy=static --topology-manager-policy=best-effort --system-reserved=memory=9000Mi --reserved-cpus="0-2
9" --container-runtime=remote --container-runtime-endpoint=unix:///var/run/containerd/containerd.sock --pod-max-pids 10000

Contents of that file is multiple lines, and not sourceable. I don't think that regex is correct or CSV, and it relies on only one option to have double quotes, and is not well anchored. Using 'grep' and 'sed' OK, but we can do directly in bash too.

The following would be a simpler equivalent to capture stuff within the double quotes and anchored against the reserved-cpus= .

if [[ $kubelet_extra_arg =~ --reserved-cpus=\"([0-9,-]+)\" ]]; then
  reserved_cpus=${BASH_REMATCH[1]}
else
  reserved_cpus=""
fi

Test for empty string:
if [[ ! -z "$var" ]]; then
move this line down below online cpus to be inline where it first used
easier to understand logic without using negate.

For clarity put correct comment within each block:
A: Replace existing reserved-cpus with refined list
B: Strip out --reserved-cpus option

Thank you both. If I understand correctly, you're saying two things: (1) that our implementation of copy_image_to_volume() and to volume_to_image() should be removed because the parent class already does it. Sorry I didn't provide a more detailed explanation.
Volume is a Oslo Versioned Object as defined in cinder/objects/volume.py and there you can see the definition of name_id:

    @property
    def name_id(self):
        return self.id if not self._name_id else self._name_id

This means that it will only return "_name_id" if it's set and will default to "id" if not.
Field "_name_id" is set when doing a migration between different backends so the user facing "id" is preserved.

So we want to migrate volume with "id" ID1 from backend B1 to backend B2, so this is briefly what Cinder does:

- creates a new empty volume in B2 of the same size (which gets "id" ID2)
- copies data from volume ID1 to volume ID2
- Call update_migrated_volume on the driver to give it the opportunity of renaming the volume from ID2 to ID1.
  * If driver can rename it, then the "_name_id" field is not used
  * If it's not renamed (driver cannot do it or the method doesn't exist), then:
    + Cinder sets the "_name_id" of the ID1 volume DB record to ID2
    + Sets the "_name_id" of the ID2 volume to ID1
    + Then it deletes the volume with "id" ID2 ("_name_id" is ID1).

This way users will always see the volume as ID1, but drivers can tell that the "id" that was used on creation is ID2 if the volume was not renamed in the backend.
THanks, we'll review all uses of id and switch to name_id where appropriate.

Lightbits LightOS is a clustered system that uses NVMe/TCP ANA support to dynamically deal with cluster changes, including LightOS cluster nodes going up and down and cluster expansion/shrink, i.e., the addition of new LightOS cluster nodes. Nova servers need to be connected (in the nvme connect sense) to all LightOS cluster nodes that have volumes accessible to those nova servers, *including new LightOS nodes that show up while the volume is already in use*. NVMe/TCP supports this through persistent discovery. Unfortunately there is incomplete/missing upstream support for NVMe/TCP discovery so we use a Lightbits provided discovery-client to handle it. The LightOS connector informs the discovery client which discovery services on the LightOS nodes to connect to and then the discovery-client takes care of nvme connecting to nodes as they show up. Long term we'd love to switch to a common connector and whatever discovery solution finds its way to Linux upstream and makes our discovery-client unnecessary, but for the time being the LightOS-specific connector and the discovery-client are required for correct operation against clustered NVMe/TCP solutions.

You are aboslutely right in general but the NVMe/TCP connector is not suitable for LightOS at this point in time. LightOS is a *clustered* NVMe/TCP system that makes use of NVMe/TCP ANA and persistent discovery, two standard NVMe/TCP features. Unfortunately some versions of the Linux kernel and nvme-cli utils do not yet do a good job of dealing with persistent discovery, so the LightOS connector uses the Lightbits discovery-client for connecting to discovery services on the LightOS cluster and establishing NVMe/TCP paths to the LightOS cluster nodes as needed. Once the NVMe/TCP ecosystem, including the openstack NVMe/TCP connector, progresses to support ANA and persistent discovvery out of the box, we'll be able to retire the discovery-client and the LightOS connector and switch to using the standard NVMe/TCP connector, but we are not there yet.

-1: The call to dsc_disconnect_volume only requests the disconnect, but doesn't actually confirm that the data has been flushed and the volume  has been disconnected.

OpenStack works under the premise that after disconnect_volume returns the volume is no longer connected to the host in any way.
-1: We still need to flush the data before this method returns.
Ack

With NVMe/TCP the disconnect is inherently an async operations susceptible to network faults. NVMe/TCP connections are not per-volume but rather host to host. With LightOS and NMVe/TCP, the actual "volume disconnection" happens after the ACL is updated so that the initiator no longer has permission to access the volume. This happens in the Cinder driver *after* the disconnect operation in the brick happens. Furthermore, updating the ACL means that the volume is no longer accessible, but it does not mean that the host necessarily knows, so the device file may stick around until some event takes place that will cause the host to remove the device file as inaccessible. Bottom line: there is no way to verify that the os-brick disconnect actually disconnects the volume. After the os-brick disconnect succeeds, Cinder will upadate the ACL and cause the volume to be disconnected.

-1: There are cases where it won't work.

Premises:

- We have an old volume named VOL_1 of a type that doesn't specify the clean_rate
- Create new volume type TYPE_N setting the clean_rate to 60
- Change storwize_svc_clean_rate config option to 60

If we ask Cinder to retype VOL_1 to TYPE_N it won't set the clean rate to 60 as it should, because the old_opts has 60 as the clean_rate (the one configured in cinder.conf) which matches the one requested in the new volume type.

The problem is that we are not differentiating when a volume type doesn't have the clean_rate defined.

Probably the easiest solution (even if it's a bit slower) is to always set the clean_rate.  Another alternative would be to store the clean_rate as part of the admin_metadata so it can be extracted regardless of the volume_type.

Consider a volume created without this patch, no cleanrate set in volume_type extra specs or  configuration. In this case, the storage will assign the default value as 50 as we didn't explicitly pass it.


Suppose we have case where:

For new volume, extraspecs clean_rate=80 : 
 - get_vdiskparams will fetch from extraspecs clean_rate=80


For old volume, created before this patchset:(will not have clean_rate extraspecs set anyway, hence it will have the default value 50 set in the storage)
 - get_vdisk params will fetch the cself.configuration.storwize_svc_clean_rate= 60(suppose)
 - for old volume, it may not fetch the actual cleanrate value(which is 50), but this condition is anyway satisfied and it sets new clean_rate=80.

Hi Brian, yes this intended because not everytime we are updating both flashcopy and clean_rate together. Hence they are handled separately.

Sure, but this design makes it *impossible* to update them at the same time.  Even worse, if the function is called like chfcmap(1234, 22, 33, 'off'), the clean_rate will be updated, but the other parameters will be silently ignored.  That is very un-obvious behavior.

In any case, this function doesn't look well designed.  Suppose that someone makes the following sequence of calls:

  chfcmap(1234, copyrate='22')
  chfcmap(1234, autodel='off')

After these two calls, autodel is off (which we want), but the copyrate is set to 50 (which we don't want, we set it to 22).

I think you need to re-think the design here.

the clean_rate will be updated, but the copyrate will be ignored.
Thanks Brian. This is fixed.

I hate to be a pest about this, but if I make the calls:

  chfcmap(autodel='off')
  chfcmap(clean_rate='55')

the second call is going to turn autodel back on again ... that doesn't seem correct to me.

Firstly the mentioned use case is not possible in our plugin, as we always want autodel ='on' by default.

Currently there are no scenarios where autodel is required as 'off'. Hence the call chfcmap(autodel='off') is never made.

In future, if the user wants autodel to be off, then chfcmap call should always be made by specifying autodel='off'

Try this (you can define a custom python file and invoke it)

import re

no_alarms = """
System Health:
All hosts are provisioned: [Fail]
1 Unprovisioned hosts
All hosts are unlocked/enabled: [OK]
All hosts have current configurations: [OK]
All hosts are patch current: [OK]
No alarms: [OK]
All kubernetes nodes are ready: [OK]
All kubernetes control plane pods are ready: [OK]
"""

def test_it(system_health):
    no_mgmt_alarms = re.findall("\[0\] of which are management affecting",
                                system_health)
    print(no_mgmt_alarms)
    if no_mgmt_alarms:
        return True
    else:
        return False

print(no_alarms)
print(test_it(no_alarms))

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
So, my problem with this patch is what happens when those mentioned patches are intentionally or unintentionally back ported?

Why are we fixing it like this, please can you give me the rationale so I understand?

Thanks,
David

If the conflicting patches were to be backported, there would be merge conflicts.
We haven't backported them before, because discussion at the time leaned towards keeping CI in stable branches simple.

As for the reason why are we doing things this way, centos8 is on its way out, and until we get our jobs to use different nodeset they will keep failing. We can either backport Takashis patch and resolve any conflicts, like we do here, or we can make our own, stable branch only patches. 

We could, hypothetically, first backport the two conflicting patches and then the nodeset change, but this would have to be done for all stable branches.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Thanks fungi for kind words.
I was considering adding more checks, and doing something like "bootstrap/pip/{{python.major}}.{{python.minor}}" version but there are no "/pip/3.{7,8,9..}", so I thought that could be the easiest thing.

> Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2
> 
> I've been dealing with this in a number of other systems, and I agree this is a fairly straightforward way to fix it.
> 
> I have a feeling we lack any jobs exercising ensure_pip_from_upstream_url so it may be a good idea for someone with such a job to try an affected platform with a Depends-On change and confirm it's not somehow subtly broken.
> 
> Also worth noting, we've tried to continue supporting use of Python 2.7 and never completely dropped 3.5 (just stopped testing it ourselves), neither of which will work with the downloaded get-pip.py script before or after this change.

Having the default support default upstream supported python installations seems reasonable though and users can override as necessary for older pythons.

Another approach is to use the oldest get-pip.py that works with as many pythons as possible. But that too will likely break eventually for much newer python in the future.
